thread.title: Wayne Hills shows fight, wins NJ championship
thread.title_full: Wayne Hills shows fight, wins NJ championship - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Wayne Hills shows fight, wins NJ championship
text:
Michael Karas/MICHAEL KARAS/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Head coach Chris Olsen instructs Wayne Hills player Dom Santoro during the Patriots' 15-12 win over Old Tappan at the Meadowlands on Saturday night. Wayne Hills went into MetLife Stadium without the nine players who were suspended after being charged with aggravated assault for allegedly beating two students from a rival school.
But the Patriots left the Meadowlands with the one thing they wanted most — a state title.
New Jersey’s most controversial team fell behind early but was able persevere for a 15-12 win over Old Tappan in Saturday’s North 1, Group 3 championship game.
Wayne Hills did it without at least one key player, all-league receiver/cornerback Andrew Monaghan , the only player charged as an adult after the Oct. 29 incident that allegedly left one student from Wayne Valley HS lying unconscious in a road. Monaghan’s criminal hearing is scheduled for next week; the other players involved are minors and have not been identified.
NJ FOOTBALL CONTROVERSY PROVES TOUGH TO TACKLE
Michael Karas/MICHAEL KARAS/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Head coach Chris Olsen instructs Wayne Hills player Dom Santoro during the Patriots' 15-12 win over Old Tappan at the Meadowlands on Saturday night. Wayne Hills fell behind 12-0 but rallied back, getting on the scoreboard on a 4-yard run by Jeff Gignac in the third quarter and then pulling ahead on a 25-yard pass from Kevin Olsen to Gignac with 3:05 left in the fourth.
After a successful two-point conversion, the Patriots recovered a fumble with 2:28 to go.
The win capped a roller coaster month for Wayne Hills, which had the suspensions lifted by the school board before public outcry led to a reversal of that ruling.
Last week, the Patriots filed a suit to get the nine players back in the game, only to have an administrative law judge and the state’s commissioner of education uphold the suspensions.
